prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The spectral windows have been set up in order to cover a frequency range between 84.5 GHz and 114.7 GHz using five scans.
The overlap between the bands have been made of ~70 MHz in order to avoid spectral window edge effects and detect the CO transition in the whole band
The chosen spectral resolution will be able to resolve the kinematic of gas in the brightest sources

The chosen angular resolution is a nice match to that of our millimetre observations (~0.6-0.7") at 1.3mm. Moreover,an angular resolution of 0.5 arcsec and a largest angular scale of 1 arcsec have been requested to achieve our goal of resolving the kinematic of gas in the brightest sources

Target: we aim to identify the redshifts of 14 faint submillimetre sources distributed in 4 fields (3-4 sources for each map). In the expected redshift range for these sources, 1<z<5.2, the most prominent millimetre spectral lines are the CO transitions.
Since we do not have the exact redshift of these sources, we will perform a spectral scan with five Science Goal. Moreover, in each Science Goal we request to point to two different fields, which are separated by only a few degrees, hence reducing the calibration time. In conclusion we have 10 Science Goals for the 4 fields. We do not select the "spectral scan" mode because the total time will be longer than performing 5 different scans. Moreover, since we know a possible photometric redshift range of some of these sources, we can set up the spectral window to increase the probability of detecting the CO emission line.
Estimated CO(J - J-1) emission: The inferred SFRs for the sources are in the range of 40 Msun/yr to 100 Msun/yr. Taking SFR=60 Msun/yr and using the relation of Kennicutt & Evans (2013) we obtain LFIR~4.0e11 Lsun. According to the LFIR-LCO relation for star-forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013) and the CO SLED (for SMGs, Carilli & Walter 2013) this corresponds to a total flux for CO(3-2) of ~0.13 Jy KM/SEC for a source at redshift z~2.5.
Sensitivity: Sources are expected to be unresolved or marginally resolved so combined with a linewidth of ~200 km/s provides an expected flux of ~0.65 mJy/beam for a source with SFR~60Msun/yr and z~2.5
With 1.31h of total observing time for Science Goal, it will be possible to reach a sensitivity over the integrated flux map of 0.22 mJy/beam, which will allow us to detect molecular gas emission line with a signal to noise of >3

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: As highlighted from recent observations, the bulk of the Cosmic Infrared Background (CIB) emission is produced by faint galaxies with star formation rates between 40 and 100 Msun/yr. In the millimeter wavelength range the number counts of this faint population can be described by a variety of galaxy evolutionary models, each of them predicting a different contribution from different types of galaxies and a specific redshift distribution for these sources. We propose ALMA observations to recover the redshift of a selection of faint sources identified by Carniani et al. (2015) with the aim of discerning between the evolutionary models that have been proposed so far. Moreover, ALMA will allow a detailed study on star-formation rates and gas kinematics for our sample galaxies, providing the first complete investigation on the faint millimeter galaxy population and solid constraints on galaxy evolutionary models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
